conclusion: A radial conductor of length r rotates at a constant angular speed ω in a uniform magnetic field B.
The radial conductor develops an induced emf ε = ½ B ω r².
All other parts of the circuit are ideal conductors, so the circuit resistance is just R.
The current is I = ε / R = (½ B ω r²) / R.
That current in the moving rod experiences a magnetic force whose tangential component produces a resisting torque τ = ½ I B r² = ¼ (B² ω r⁴) / R.
To keep the rod rotating uniformly, the external agent must supply a torque of the same magnitude.
The mechanical power delivered by the external agent is P = τ ω = ¼ (B² ω² r⁴) / R.
The power that the external force must supply is P = (B² r⁴ ω²) / (4 R).
